results.title: The Birth of a handicapped baby
results.creator_credit: Tony Vuletich, Margaret Nicol and V and A Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Understanding maternal grief”.
Why? Why did this happen to me? This video looks at the grief reaction women following the birth of a disabled baby. Effects of long term stress and the impact of unresolved grief are illustrated through an interview with the mother of a teenage child born with severe disabilities.

results.title: Neonatal death
results.creator_credit: Tony Vuletich, Margaret Nicol and V and A Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Understanding maternal grief”.
It is difficult to imagine the full impact of neonatal death on those women who are mothers for the shortest time. This video discusses the effects of the death of a baby on women’s mental and physical health. The grief process is viewed within the context of a wide range of stresses experienced by a woman and her fanily during this major life crisis including the impact of a premature birth: the stresses associated with having a seriously ill baby in neonatal intensive care: the difficulties in decision-making related to medical interventions: the consideration of siblings and their inclusion in the bonding and grief experiences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Vuletich, Margaret Nicol and V and A Productions

results.title: Miscarriage and stillbirth
results.creator_credit: Tony Vuletich, Margaret Nicol and V and A Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Understanding maternal grief”.
Miscarriage, although not uncommon, is a cause of deep grief and shock among women who have experienced it. With stillbirth, the grief often runs deeper for those women who are already mothers. In this video woman is interviewed who has experienced miscarriages and a stillbirth. Through her story we are able to understand more clearly the psychological needs of bereaved women and the resultant impact on women’s health when these are not met.

results.title: Infertility and adoption
results.creator_credit: Tony Vuletich, Margaret Nicol and V and A Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Understanding maternal grief”.
Infertility is perhaps the most unacknowledged and painful grief in our society - truly the death of a dream. While addressing major psychological issues encountered by infertile women, this programme also discuuses the option of medical intervention by outlining the benefits, the additional stress it can cause and the impact on relationships.

results.title: The Golden years of surf collection
results.brief_description: Surfing films have always been visually spectacular. The Virgin collection captures some of surfing’s finest.
results.description: Surfing films have always been visually spectacular. The Virgin collection captures some of surfing’s finest.
description_for_label: Surfing films have always been visually spectacular. The Virgin collection captures some of surfing’s finest.

group_works.title: The Endless summer
group_works.creator_credit: Bruce Brown and Bruce Brown Films

results.title: The Endless summer
results.creator_credit: Bruce Brown and Bruce Brown Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Golden years of surf collection”.
The archetypal surfing film of the 1960’s, Bruce Brown defied all odds to produce one of the most successful feature-length documentary films in movie history. Filmed on locations world-wide, with diverting tongue-in- cheek narrative by Brown, we follow two surfers’ quest for the ultimate wave. The heady surfing days of the sixties are forever captured in this classic.

group.title: The Golden years of surf collection

results.title: Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II
results.brief_description: The second series of Archival Film Programs on Australian writers contains minimally-edited interviews with writers at home and at ease. We listen to their anecdotes, personal philosophies and are given a rare insight into their influences and motivations. These archival interviews are unique slices of social history and provide a picture of early Australia.

results.title: Elizabeth Riddell
results.creator_credit: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Elizabeth Riddell came to Australia from New Zealand when she was eighteen. She recalls the community of artists and writers in Sydney in the 1930’s and her early experiences as a journalist. During the Second World War Riddell reported from North America and travelled through Europe. On her return to Australia, her long autobiographical poem was published. Riddell discusses the conflict between the demands of her career and her desire to write poetry. She speaks about the discipline of writing and the state of contemporary Australian literature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions

results.title: Dorothy Green
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Poet, journalist, author and academic, Dorothy Green speaks of her early childhood in England. She recalls the atmosphere of Sydney University in the 1930’s and her early success as a poet which led to a career in journalism. Green worked as a teacher and university lecturer in 1972, a grant enabled her to devote herself to writing. Green reads and discusses several of her poems and speaks of her spiritual beliefs and attitudes towards death. Interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Colin Thiele
results.creator_credit: Peter Campbell, AFI [au] and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Author, poet and biographer, Colin Thiele recalls his childhood in the German migrant community north of the Barossa Valley and his early love of literature. Thiele remembers his student days and his association with movements such as the Angry Penguins. He also discusses the effect on his life and work of his long battle with rheumatoid arthritis and reads a poem about the isolation of pain.
